title: Sir Bernard Ingham lifts lid on Westland crisis
text:
Sir Bernard Ingham lifts lid on Westland crisis By WMNAGreenwood | Posted: October 14, 2015 Sir Bernard Ingham pictured in 1986 Sir Bernard Ingham lifts lid on Westland crisis X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
Sir Bernard Ingham, who was Margaret Thatcher’s press secretary, spoke for the first time today about the 1986 Westland Helicopters crisis which came close to toppling her from power. 
Writing in the Yorkshire Post he fiercely denied new allegations that he was part of a conspiracy to leak to the Press Association a crucial letter, adding that leaking was anathema to the then prime minister. 
The letter from a law officer to Michael Heseltine, then defence secretary, criticised his stance over the affair. 
The crisis arose because of a public clash between Heseltine and Thatcher of how to rescue the ailing West Country helicopter company. 
Sir Bernard said: “Heseltine went mad with frustrated ambition disguised as a severe case of eurohysteria. He contested Thatcher’s euroscepticism by insisting Westland should be taken over by a non-existent euro-consortium instead of finding its own salvation. 
“It eventually did, with USA’s Sikorsky. Unfortunately, Leon Brittan, trade and industry secretary, and responsible for Westland, was no match for Tarzan on the media rampage. 
“Things got so bad that Brittan sought Heseltine’s dismissal.” 
Sir Bernard said that senior ministers and the cabinet secretary, Sir Robert Armstrong, were summoned by Thatcher. 
“I was asked: ‘So, he should be sacked?’ I said he might well deserve it but then was not the time. He was winning in the eyes of the media.” 
Later, he said, the head of information at DTI Colette Bowe rang him saying she had now got permission to leak the letter. 
“I had no idea a leak was proposed and Bowe did not tell me, as is claimed, that No 10 wanted it leaked. I said I did not like the idea at all. She then told me the DTI wanted me to leak the letter. 
“I refused point blank, saying ‘I have to keep the prime minister above this sort of thing’. Leaking was anathema to her. 
“I regret I did not tell Bowe not to leak instead of effectively saying ‘on your head be it’, but I certainly had no right to countermand Brittan’s decision.” 
He said that Charles Moore, in his second volume of the late prime minister’s memoirs, accurately portrays all this as government falling apart, with clashes of egos, massive hypocrisy and general chaos. 
Sir Bernard added: “In such ways can prime ministerial careers be threatened. I plead not guilty to being part of any conspiracy.” 
Later both Heseltine and Brittan resigned from office.
